choices.text: Life expectancy at birth, literacy and standard of living
Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and standard of living
Infant mortality rate, literacy and standard of living
Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and infant mortality rate

questions.text: You are a global health researcher working on a report assessing the development status of various countries. To classify the countries and compare them, you decide to use the Human Development Index (HDI). You recall that HDI is a commonly utilized measure but seek to clarify its exact components, as presented by organizations like the World Health Organization (WHO). Which of the following correctly identifies the components that make up the HDI? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Life expectancy at birth, literacy and standard of living 

 

Human Development Index (HDI)

 

The Human Development Index (HDI) is a composite statistic used to rank countries based on human development levels. It consists of three main components:

 

  • Life Expectancy at Birth: Measures the average number of years a newborn is expected to live.
  • Education (Literacy and Mean Years of Schooling): Assesses the average number of years of education received by people ages 25 and older and the expected years of schooling for children entering school.
  • Standard of Living (Gross National Income per capita): Adjusted for purchasing power parity (PPP).

 

Note -

 

  • HDI values range: 0 to + 1
  • HDI India is 0. 633 (Rank 134 out of 186 countries)
  • Human poverty index [HPI] is complementary to HDI

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: You're a clinician in a busy urban sexual health clinic, and it's been a hectic day with multiple patients presenting with sexually transmitted infections (STIs). The STI treatment kits are color-coded for efficient management, but the new nurse seems a bit overwhelmed with the options. You decide to guide her. Based on the clinical presentation, which color-coded STI kit would you suggest for the following symptoms? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) A-4, B-1, C-3, D-2

 

A. Lower abdominal pain:

 

  • Correct Kit: Yellow, Kit 6, which includes Cefixime, Metronidazole, and Doxycycline, specifically designed to manage symptoms like lower abdominal pain, which can be associated with pelvic inflammatory disease or other related conditions.

 

B. Urethral discharge:

 

  • Correct Kit: Grey, Kit 1, which contains Azithromycin and Cefixime. This kit is ideal for treating symptoms like urethral discharge, which can indicate infections such as gonorrhea or chlamydia.

 

C. Non-herpetic genital ulcer:

 

  • Correct Kit: White, Kit 3, equipped with Azithromycin and Penicillin, suitable for treating non-herpetic genital ulcers, often caused by syphilis or chancroid.

 

D. Vaginal discharge:

 

  • Correct Kit: Green, Kit 2, which contains Secnidazole and Fluconazole, tailored for treating vaginal discharge that could be due to bacterial vaginosis or yeast infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The National Aids Control Organization (NACO has provided color-coded kits for the syndromic management of sexually transmitted diseases:

questions.text: A resident in neurology is assessing a patient who recently sustained a traumatic brain injury using the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS). How should the resident describe the type of data obtained from the GCS? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Ordinal scale data

 

  • The Glasgow Coma Scale represents ordinal data since the GCS score is categorized as mild, moderate, or severe, following a specific order of severity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nominal scale data: Data based on names without a specific order.

 

Option C. Alphanumerical data: Data that includes both letters and numbers, not applicable here.

 

Option D. Interval scale data: Data measured along a scale where each point is equidistant from the next, but GCS does not meet this criterion.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the recommended dietary allowance for iodine dosage among lactating women in India? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 280 µg/day

 

As per the 2020 guidelines from the National Institute of Nutrition (NIN), the suggested dietary intake of iodine for lactating women in India is 280 micrograms per day.

 

NIN guidelines on recommended dietary allowance of Iodine -

 

 

Educational Objective:  

 

India had adopted WHO guideline of Iodine requirement 150 mcg per day in Adults, 250 mcg per day in Pregnancy and 280 mcg per day in Lactation

questions.text: Which of the following is the best level of prevention of breast cancer? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Early diagnosis and treatment

 

Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial in the management of breast cancer. This involves screening methods such as mammography, which can detect cancer at an early stage when it is more likely to be treated successfully. Early treatment can significantly improve survival rates and outcomes for patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Specific protection: Specific protection involves preventive measures that protect against specific diseases, such as vaccinations or using protective equipment. Currently, there is no vaccine or specific protective measure that can prevent breast cancer.

 

Option C. Disability limitation: Disability limitation is part of tertiary prevention and focuses on minimizing the impact of an ongoing illness that has already caused some level of disability. It involves strategies to prevent complications and further disability. This is more applicable after a disease has been diagnosed and is not the best level of prevention for breast cancer.

 

Option D. Rehabilitation: Rehabilitation is also a part of tertiary prevention and aims to help individuals recover as much function as possible after a disease has caused disability. It includes therapies to restore physical, psychological, and social functioning. While important, it is not the best preventive strategy for breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early diagnosis and treatment (secondary prevention) are the most effective methods for preventing the progression of breast cancer, as they allow for early detection and intervention, significantly improving the chances of successful treatment and reducing mortality rates.

choices.text: Urgent referral to the tertiary care centre immediately
Administer IV antibiotics and ask the patient to be brought after 24 hours

questions.text: A 2-year-old toddler with a weight of 11 kg was brought to the pediatric outpatient department. The child exhibited a respiratory rate of 38 breaths per minute and upon examination, noticeable chest indrawing was detected. What is the next step of management? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Oral amoxicillin for five days

 

According to the latest revised guidelines by WHO, the management of childhood pneumonia has been updated based on new evidence. In the given scenario, a 2-year-old child presents with a respiratory rate of 38 breaths per minute and chest indrawing, which fits the criteria for pneumonia but without general danger signs. According to the revised classification, the appropriate management for this case is oral amoxicillin for five days and home care advice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urgent referral to the tertiary care centre immediately: This is recommended for children showing general danger signs or very severe disease, not for pneumonia with chest indrawing without other danger signs.

 

Option C. Administer IV antibiotics and ask the patient to be brought after 24 hours: This would be applicable for severe cases requiring inpatient care, not for managing a case of pneumonia without general danger signs at an outpatient department.

 

Option D. Start antipyretics urgently: While antipyretics may be used to manage fever, they do not address the underlying pneumonia and are not the primary management step in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: After a road traffic accident case has been admitted, there is a blood spillage on the hospital floor. Which type of disinfectant would you select for cleaning the floor? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Sodium hypochlorite

 

If there is spillage of blood on the hospital floor, sodium hypochlorite is the recommended disinfectant for cleaning the floor.

 

Procedure to be followed in the event of blood/body fluid spillage:

 

  1. Wear a pair of non-sterile gloves
  2. Broken glass (if any) of the container is cleaned first using tongs or a pan and brush and discarded in the sharp container. Caution is taken to not use hands.
  3. Disposable paper towels are used to absorb as much as possible.
  4. Water and detergent are used to clean the surface until visibly clean.
  5. The area is saturated with 0.5% Sodium Hypochlorite. This is prepared by diluting 5.25% sodium hypochlorite bleach at a 1:10 ratio.
  6. The tongs, pan, and brush are washed under running water and left to dry
  7. The gloves are removed and discarded.
  8. Hands are washed with soap and water using proper technique and dried with a disposable towel.
  9. The spillage is recorded in an incident book.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ethyl alcohol: Is not recommended for cleaning surfaces with blood spills as it is less effective against some microorganisms and may evaporate too quickly.

 

Option B. Chlorhexidine: is also less effective against blood-borne pathogens and is better suited for skin disinfection.

 

Option D. Formaldehyde: Is not commonly used as a disinfectant due to its potential health hazards.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For effective disinfection of surfaces contaminated with blood spills, sodium hypochlorite is the preferred choice due to its broad-spectrum antimicrobial activity and ability to neutralize blood-borne pathogens.

questions.text: Which of the following steps is not included in WHO's STEP approach?[NEET  PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Therapeutic assessment

 

  • STEPwise approach to surveillance (STEPS) is a simple, standardized method by WHO for surveillance. It is of two types:
    • STEPwise approach to chronic disease risk factor surveillance
    • STEPwise approach to Stroke surveillance

questions.text: What is the next best step in the management of a 16-year-old male with a painless large round firm right testicular swelling, with a dragging sensation and AFP around 5000? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High inguinal orchidectomy

 

Testicular mass with elevated AFP is suggestive of testicular tumor, where the next best step in management for this patient is High inguinal orchidectomy

 

This is the correct choice for the initial management of a suspected malignant testicular tumor. The inguinal approach ensures that the scrotal skin and potential lymphatic drainage are not violated. This procedure allows for both definitive diagnosis (through histopathological examination) and therapeutic management by removing the tumor. An elevated AFP further supports the possibility of a germ cell tumor, such as a yolk sac tumor or non-seminomatous germ cell tumor, both of which warrant surgical removal

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FNAC (Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology): While FNAC is a diagnostic procedure, it's not typically used in the primary evaluation of testicular masses due to the risk of tumor seeding along the needle track and is contraindicated.

 

Option B. Scrotal trucut biopsy: This is not recommended for suspected testicular tumors. Biopsying a testicular tumor through a scrotal approach can risk tumor spillage or seeding within the scrotum and can alter the lymphatic drainage pattern, thus complicating future treatment..

 

Option D. Repeat Tumor markers: While monitoring tumor markers like AFP is useful in the management and follow-up of testicular cancer, simply repeating the test without addressing the testicular mass would not be appropriate. The clinical findings and elevated AFP already provide strong evidence of malignancy, and action should be taken.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A painless testicular swelling in a young male with elevated AFP is highly suggestive of a testicular malignancy. The standard of care in such cases is to proceed with a high inguinal orchidectomy for both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes.

choices.text: Upper GI endoscopy and 24-hour PH monitoring

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the clinic with a complaint of difficulty in swallowing both solids and liquids for the last eight months. A barium swallow test has been conducted, and the results are available for review. What further investigations are required for this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Upper GI endoscopy & Manometry

 

The given scenario of long standing dysphagia in a 45 year old, with barium swallow showing smooth tapering is suggestive of achalasia. Next investigations would be upper GI endoscopy (to rule of cancer) and esophageal manometry (IOC).

 

  • Upper GI endoscopy: This procedure involves a visual examination of the esophagus, allowing the physician to see any obstructions, lesions, or abnormalities that could be causing dysphagia like cancer
  • Manometry: Manometry measures the pressures and coordinated muscle contractions of the esophagus. It's particularly helpful for conditions like achalasia, where there's an absence of normal esophageal peristalsis and increased lower esophageal sphincter tone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Upper GI endoscopy & PET scan: While a PET scan can identify metabolic activity and might be useful in detecting metastasis, it isn't a first-line test for dysphagia. The primary concern with dysphagia is often mechanical or functional obstruction, which a PET scan wouldn't directly address.

 

Option C. Upper GI endoscopy & CECT: CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography) can provide images of the esophagus, but it is not the primary modality for evaluating dysphagia. While it can identify masses or structural issues, it doesn't offer functional insights like manometry.

 

Option D. Upper GI endoscopy and 24-hour PH monitoring: 24-hour pH monitoring assesses the acidity in the esophagus over 24 hours. While it can be valuable for diagnosing conditions like GERD, it's not the primary investigation for dysphagia unless reflux symptoms are predominant

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Achalasia is a disorder of the esophagus characterized by absent peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the LES.
  • Manometry is the most sensitive test to diagnose achalasia and can identify early disease before esophageal dilatation and food retention.
  • The diagnostic criteria for achalasia with manometry are impaired LES relaxation, absent peristalsis, and elevated LES pressure. Subtypes are classified according to Chicago classification as Type 1 (classical), Type 2 (pan-esophageal pressurisation) and type 3 (Spastic).
  • Endoscopy can rule out pseudo achalasia/carcinoma.

choices.text: Triangle of death and circle of death
Triangle of doom and circle of death
Triangle of doom medially and triangle of pain laterally
Triangle of doom laterally and triangle of pain medially

questions.text: The Trapezoid of Disaster includes: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Triangle of doom medially and triangle of pain laterally

 

Explanation:

 

During laparoscopic hernia repair, the surgeon must navigate important anatomical landmarks in the inguinal region. The "Trapezoid of Disaster" contains two important triangles that require careful attention during mesh placement. The Triangle of Doom is bounded medially by the vas deferens and laterally by the testicular vessels, containing the external iliac vessels and genital branch of genitofemoral nerve. The Triangle of Pain is located lateral to this, bounded medially by testicular vessels and laterally by the iliopubic tract, containing the femoral nerve, anterior cutaneous nerve of thigh, and lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: "Triangle of death" is anatomically known as the triangle of “doom”.
  • Option B: "Triangle of doom and circle of death" do not form a trapezoid of disaster.
  • Option D: This reverses the correct orientation. The Triangle of Doom is medial and the Triangle of Pain is lateral, not the opposite.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Triangle of Doom contains vital vascular structures (external iliac vessels) while the Triangle of Pain contains important nerves (femoral nerve, cutaneous nerves). Accurate identification of these anatomical landmarks is crucial to prevent iatrogenic injury during laparoscopic hernia repair.

questions.text: Open pre-peritoneal large mesh repair for complex inguinal hernia is associated with which of the following procedures? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Stoppa operation

 

Explanation:

            

The Stoppa operation is the open pre-peritoneal large mesh repair technique for complex inguinal hernias. This procedure involves placing a large prosthetic mesh in the pre-peritoneal space that covers the entire myopectineal orifice bilaterally. It's specifically designed for complex, recurrent, or bilateral inguinal hernias. The Stoppa approach provides excellent coverage of all potential hernia sites while avoiding direct contact with nerves in the inguinal canal, reducing the risk of chronic pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lichtenstein operation - Incorrect because the Lichtenstein repair is an onlay mesh technique where the prosthetic mesh is placed on top of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal, not in the pre-peritoneal space. While it uses mesh, it employs a different anatomical approach and placement technique.

 

Option B. Shouldice operation - Incorrect because the Shouldice repair is a tissue-based herniorrhaphy technique that doesn't use mesh at all. It involves multiple layers of suturing of the native tissue (double breasting of conjoint tendon and inguinal ligament and halves of fascia transversalis) to create a 4-layer posterior wall repair.

 

Option D. Mac-Vay Operation - Incorrect because the McVay (Cooper ligament) repair is another tissue-based repair that doesn't utilize mesh. This technique involves suturing the conjoint tendon to Cooper's ligament (pectineal ligament) rather than to the inguinal ligament.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Stoppa operation is characterized by placement of a large prosthetic mesh in the pre-peritoneal space for complex inguinal hernias, covering bilateral myopectineal orifices simultaneously.

questions.text: Hepatic avulsions are classified as what grade according to the AAST liver injury scale? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Grade V 

 

Explanation:

 

Hepatic avulsions are classified as Grade V in the AAST liver injury scale. This represents the highest grade of liver injury, reflecting complete detachment of the liver or severe damage to major vascular pedicles. The AAST grading system categorizes liver injuries progressively from minor lacerations to complete avulsion, with Grade V being the most severe form.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grade I - Incorrect Grade I liver injuries only involve minor lacerations less than 1cm in depth. These are superficial injuries that don't involve vascular structures and typically heal without surgical intervention.

 

Option B. Grade II - Incorrect Grade II liver injuries involve lacerations between 1-3cm in depth but don't involve major vascular structures. These moderate injuries are far less severe than complete avulsions.

 

Option C. Grade IV - Incorrect Grade IV liver injuries involve parenchymal disruption affecting 25-75% of one hepatic lobe. While serious, these don't constitute complete avulsion of the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatic avulsion represents the most severe form of liver trauma in the AAST classification system and is designated as Grade V. Management of such injuries typically requires damage control surgery with the "4 Ps" approach: Push, Pack, Plug, and Pringle maneuver.

questions.text: Which of the following types of renal stones are produced by laxative abuse? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ammonium urate

 

Ammonium urate stones are most likely to be seen in patients with laxative abuse.

 

Ammonium urate stones are composed of a combination of ammonia and uric acid. When laxatives are abused, they cause metabolic alkalosis. This alkaline environment can lead to the formation of ammonium urate stones, as ammonium is more soluble in alkaline urine than in acidic urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uric acid: Uric acid stones form when the urine is persistently acidic, which can occur in conditions like gout or diseases that cause rapid cell turnover like tumor lysis syndrome. A diet high in purines, certain types of medications, and some genetic factors can contribute to uric acid stone formation. However, these stones are not typically associated with laxative abuse.

 

Option C. Struvite: Struvite stones, also known as infection stones, are associated with urinary tract infections caused by certain bacteria. These bacteria can produce urease, which splits urea in to ammonia, that makes the urine more alkaline, which can lead to struvite stone formation. They are not directly associated with laxative abuse.

 

Option D. Calcium oxalate: Calcium oxalate stones are the most common type of kidney stone. Factors that increase the urine concentration of these constituents can contribute to stone formation. The absorption of oxalate might increase with chronic diarrhea (a potential consequence of laxative abuse), which can contribute to the formation of calcium oxalate stones, however this is not a common feature.

 

Educational Objective:


Laxative abuse can lead to metabolic alkalosis, which creates an alkaline urinary environment, predisposing to the formation of ammonium urate stones.

choices.text: Junction of upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle
Junction of middle and lower third of the sternomastoid muscle
Between the two heads of the sternomastoid muscle

questions.text: Which of these is the most common site of a branchial cyst? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Junction of upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle

Explanation:

 

The typical location for a branchial cyst is at the anterior border of the junction between the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle. Branchial cysts are developmental anomalies that arise from the remnants of the second branchial cleft. They are lined by squamous epithelium and contain thick, cloudy fluid that often includes cholesterol crystals. This location is key for identifying and diagnosing branchial cysts.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Junction of middle and lower third of the sternomastoid muscle: This location is typically associated with the external opening of a branchial fistula, not a branchial cyst.

 

Option C. Middle of the sternomastoid muscle: This is not the usual site for branchial cysts. Branchial cysts are more commonly found at the anterior border of the upper and middle third junction.

 

Option D. Between the two heads of the sternomastoid muscle: This area is not associated with the typical location of branchial cysts. The cysts are more commonly found anterior to the sternomastoid muscle.

 

Additional Information on Branchial Cysts:

  • Origin: Congenital or acquired remnants of the second branchial cleft.
  • Lining: Squamous epithelium.
  • Contents: Thick, cloudy fluid with cholesterol crystals, sometimes clear fluid making the cyst soft and shiny.
  • Branchial Fistula: The external opening of a branchial fistula is at the junction of the middle and lower third of the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common site for a branchial cyst is at the anterior border of the junction between the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle.

choices.text: Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery
Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery

questions.text: A 60-year-old man, a habitual smoker, visits the hospital. He describes experiencing recurring pain in his thighs and buttocks when he walks, particularly noticeable after covering a distance of approximately 500 meters. What could be a plausible diagnosis for his symptoms?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of arterial disease with intermittent claudication due to aortoiliac occlusion. Claudication pain in the buttocks and thighs, particularly during walking, is a typical symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease, also known as Leriche syndrome in more severe cases if associated with impotence.
  • The aortoiliac arteries are major blood vessels that supply the lower half of the body. Blockages in these arteries can lead to pain in the buttocks, thighs, or hips upon exertion. The claudication pain in the buttocks or thighs, as described by the patient, is a typical symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease. Therefore, this is the most plausible diagnosis given the patient's symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery: This type of arterial disease would involve blockage in the superficial femoral artery, which runs through the thigh. Patients with this condition typically experience claudication pain in the calf muscles because the superficial femoral artery primarily supplies the calf muscles.

 

Option C. Femoral venous insufficiency: Femoral venous insufficiency involves issues with the veins, not the arteries. This condition typically leads to symptoms like leg swelling, varicose veins, and skin changes, but it does not cause claudication or pain upon walking specific distances.

 

Option D. Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery: The profunda femoris artery is a deep artery of the thigh. Blockage in this artery can cause pain, but the pain would typically present differently from the described scenario. The location and type of pain would be more localized to the thigh rather than involving the buttocks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Claudication pain in the buttocks and thighs during walking, particularly in a habitual smoker, is highly suggestive of arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement. This is characterized by blockages in the aortoiliac arteries, leading to decreased blood flow to the lower extremities.

choices.text: Varenicline comes with a black box warning of cardiovascular death
There should be a 15-minute gap between nicotine gum and coffee/soda/acidic food as they decrease its absorption
Nicotine chewing gum is better for constant use as it gives 25% higher blood level than lozenges

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding nicotine substitution therapy? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) There should be a 15-minute gap between nicotine gum and coffee/soda/acidic food as they decrease its absorption.

 

 Acidic beverages can interfere with nicotine gum's absorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Preferably given by gastrointestinal route: Incorrect. NRT is not given via the gastrointestinal route. Nicotine in NRT is absorbed either through buccal mucosa or skin.

 

Option B. Varenicline comes with a black box warning of cardiovascular death: Incorrect. Varenicline doesn’t come with this black box warning.

 

Option D. Nicotine chewing gum is better for constant use as it gives 25% higher blood level than lozenges: Incorrect. Choice between gum and lozenges depends on individual preference, not blood levels.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) is an effective method to assist in smoking cessation. It is used to relieve craving for tobacco by substituting nicotine in tobacco with nicotine in safer forms. Various preparations include nicotine gums, nicotine lozenges, nicotine patch, nicotine spray and nicotine inhaler. Nicotine gum's absorption can be affected by acidic beverages, so it's advised to avoid them shortly before or while using the gum.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 684.

questions.text: What is 'mental retardation' now called according to the American Psychiatric Association in its revision of DSM-5? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intellectual disability

 

The term "mental retardation" has historically been used in clinical and diagnostic settings, but it has now been largely replaced due to its potential for stigmatization and pejorative connotations. In the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition (DSM-5) by the American Psychiatric Association, the term "mental retardation" has been updated to: Intellectual disability (intellectual developmental disorder). This term is more respectful and emphasizes the abilities of the individual, rather than just their limitations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Feeble mindedness and option B. Mental subnormality are outdated and non-specific terms that were used in the past.

 

Option D. Intellectually challenged is a non-clinical term that may be used colloquially to describe someone with intellectual disabilities in a more respectful manner.

 

Educational Objective:

 

It's essential to understand that the term "mental retardation" is now outdated and has been replaced with "intellectual disability" in clinical settings, especially according to DSM-5, to ensure respectful and non-stigmatizing communication.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 1118-1119.

questions.text: Premature ejaculation is a disorder of which phase of the normal sexual cycle? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Orgasm

 

This phase involves the release of sexual tension. Premature ejaculation and anorgasmia are disorders of this phase.

 

Premature ejaculation is a disorder of the orgasm phase of the sexual response cycle. It involves ejaculation that occurs earlier than desired, often with minimal sexual stimulation.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Desire: This phase refers to the interest in engaging in sexual activity. Disorders of this phase might manifest as hypoactive sexual desire disorder or sexual aversion disorder.

 

Option B. Arousal: This phase is characterized by physiological changes such as erection in men and vaginal lubrication in women. Erectile dysfunction is a disorder of this phase in men.

 

Option D. Pain: This isn't a phase of the sexual response cycle. However, dyspareunia refers to pain during intercourse and can be a clinical condition.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Premature ejaculation is a disorder of the orgasm phase of the sexual response cycle. It is characterized by a pattern of persistent or recurrent ejaculation with minimal sexual stimulation before or immediately after the vaginal penetration.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 579.

questions.text: Fibres of the given structure originate from? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hippocampus

 

Explanation:

 

The given structure is the fornix and its fibres arise from the hippocampus.

 

The fornix is a C-shaped bundle of white matter fibers that connects the hippocampus to other regions of the brain, including the mammillary bodies, thalamus, and septal nuclei. The fibers of the fornix arise from the hippocampus, which is involved in the formation and consolidation of memories, and then project through the fornix to other parts of the limbic system. Dysfunction of the fornix and hippocampus can result in memory impairments, as seen in conditions such as Alzheimer's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amygdala: The amygdala is a small almond-shaped structure located deep within the temporal lobes of the brain. It is involved in processing emotions, especially fear and emotional memory. While the amygdala does have connections to the limbic system, it is not a direct source of fibers for the fornix. However, it does interact with the hippocampus and other limbic structures.

 

Option B. Mammillary Body: The mammillary bodies are a pair of small, round structures located on the undersurface of the brain, specifically in the diencephalon. They are closely connected to the hippocampus and are considered part of the limbic system. The fornix sends fibers to and receives fibers from the mammillary bodies, facilitating the flow of information within the limbic circuit.

 

Option C. Caudate Nucleus: The caudate nucleus is a component of the basal ganglia and is involved in motor control and cognitive functions. While it interacts with some limbic structures, it is not a primary source of fornix fibers. Instead, it has connections with other regions involved in motor control and reward processing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hippocampus is a critical structure within the limbic system that plays a central role in memory formation and spatial navigation. It is the primary source of fibers that make up the fornix. The fornix carries information from the hippocampus to other limbic structures, including the mammillary bodies and the anterior thalamic nuclei, as well as to the septal nuclei and the cingulate gyrus.

questions.text:
Which of the following cells are present in the molecular layer of the cerebellum?(INICET MAY 2022)

 

1. Stellate cells

2. Basket cells

3. Purkinje cells

4. Granular cells
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1, 2

 

The molecular layer of the cerebellum contains stellate and basket cells.

 

The molecular layer is one of the three layers of the cerebellar cortex, along with the granular layer and the Purkinje cell layer. It is involved in the processing of sensory information, as well as motor planning and coordination. The stellate and basket cells within the molecular layer provide inhibitory feedback to the Purkinje cells, which are the only output neurons of the cerebellar cortex.

 

The parallel fibres, which originate from granule cells in the granular layer, run perpendicular to the Purkinje cell dendrites and provide excitatory input to the molecular layer. As the parallel fibres traverse the molecular layer, they make multiple synapses with the dendrites of Purkinje cells, where inhibitory synapses are formed. This allows the Purkinje cells to integrate the incoming excitatory and inhibitory signals and adjust their output accordingly.

 

Overall, the molecular layer plays a crucial role in the cerebellar circuitry and contributes to the precision of motor movements and balance.

 

 

1. Stellate cells:

  • Location: Stellate cells are present in the molecular layer of the cerebellum.
  • Function: These are inhibitory interneurons that primarily release GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) and inhibit the dendrites of Purkinje cells.
     

2. Basket cells:

  • Location: Basket cells are also located in the molecular layer of the cerebellum.
  • Function: These are another type of inhibitory interneuron. The axons of basket cells form "baskets" around the cell bodies of Purkinje cells, releasing GABA and inhibiting them.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Purkinje cells:

  • Location: Purkinje cells form their own distinct layer known as the Purkinje cell layer, which is situated between the molecular layer and the granular layer.
  • Function: These cells are the primary output neurons of the cerebellar cortex. They have large, flattened dendritic trees that extend into the molecular layer, receiving inputs from climbing fibers and parallel fibers. The axons of Purkinje cells send inhibitory projections to the cerebellar nuclei.
     

4. Granular cells:

  • Location: Granular cells are present in the granular layer, which is the innermost layer of the cerebellar cortex.
  • Function: These cells receive inputs from mossy fibers, which originate from various brainstem nuclei and the spinal cord. Granular cells send their axons into the molecular layer, where they bifurcate to form parallel fibers. These parallel fibers synapse onto the dendrites of Purkinje cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The molecular layer of the cerebellum primarily contains stellate and basket cells. This layer is one of three distinct layers of the cerebellar cortex and is crucial for integrating sensory and motor information to refine motor coordination and balance.

questions.text: The marked structure develops from which of the following structures? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Supracardinal vein

 

The supracardinal vein gives rise to the structure indicated in the provided figure, which is the azygos vein.

 

The vein network known as the azygos system serves as a conduit between the superior and inferior venae caves. It resides in the posterior mediastinum and higher portion of the posterior abdominal wall. Moreover, it links the vertebral venous, caval, and portal systems. It drains the top part of the lumbar spine and the thoracic wall.

 

Development: The azygos venous system arises from the supra cardinal veins embryologically. The right supra cardinal vein becomes the azygos vein, while the left supra cardinal vein becomes the hemiazygos vein.

 

  • The 4th to 11th right intercostal veins empties into the right supracardinal vein, which together with a portion of the posterior cardinal vein forms the azygos vein.
  • On the left, the 4th to 7th intercostal veins enters into the left supracardinal vein, and the left supracardinal vein, then known as the hemiazygos vein, which also empties into the azygos vein.
  • Cardinal veins form the main venous drainage system of the embryo. It consists of,
  • Anterior cardinal veins, which drain the cephalic part of the embryo, and
  • Posterior cardinal veins, which drain the rest of the embryo.

 

During the fifth to the seventh weeks, a number of additional veins are formed. It includes,

 

  • Subcardinal veins, which mainly drain the kidneys;
  • Sacrocardinal veins, which drain the lower extremities;
  • Supracardinal veins, which drain the body wall by way of the intercostal veins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Common cardinal vein: common cardinal veins drain the embryonic body into the sinus venosus. These are early, primitive venous systems that mainly regress but give rise to parts of the systemic venous system. Specifically, the common cardinal vein will give rise to the sinus venarum of the right atrium and the oblique vein of the left atrium.

 

Option B. Anterior cardinal vein: The anterior cardinal veins develop later and drain the cranial part of the embryo. With further development, the bilateral anterior cardinal veins will form the internal jugular vein and the brachiocephalic vein after some remodeling and anastomosis. It does not directly contribute to the formation of the azygos vein system.

 

Option D. Subcardinal vein: The subcardinal veins primarily play a role in the development of the renal and gonadal venous systems. They give rise to the renal segment of the inferior vena cava and the gonadal veins. They do not directly contribute to the formation of the azygos vein system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The supracardinal veins develop in the embryo as paired structures and are involved in the drainage of the body wall. On the right side, the supracardinal vein becomes the azygos vein, while on the left side, it contributes to the formation of the hemiazygos and accessory hemiazygos veins.

choices.text: Primary active transport
Facilitated diffusion
Simple diffusion
Secondary active transport

questions.text: Which of the following process is responsible for glucose absorption into the intestine?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Secondary active transport

 

Explanation   

 

Glucose is absorbed into the intestine by secondary active transport because this process allows for the efficient uptake of glucose against its concentration gradient.

 

Secondary active transport involves the coupled movement of two substances across a membrane, where the movement of one substance is dependent on the electrochemical gradient created by the movement of another substance. In the case of glucose absorption in the intestine, the secondary active transport mechanism relies on the sodium gradient created by the sodium-potassium pump.

 

The process of glucose absorption in the intestine occurs in the brush border membrane of the intestinal epithelial cells, specifically in the small intestine. Here's a step-by-step explanation of how secondary active transport facilitates glucose absorption:

 

  1. Sodium-Potassium Pump: The sodium-potassium pump actively transports sodium ions (Na+) out of the epithelial cells and into the intercellular space, using ATP energy. This creates a concentration gradient where the sodium concentration is higher outside the cell.
  2. Sodium-Glucose Cotransporter: The sodium gradient generated by the sodium-potassium pump is utilized by a specific protein called the sodium-glucose cotransporter (SGLT). This cotransporter binds both sodium ions and glucose molecules on the outer surface of the cell.
  3. Co-transport of Sodium and Glucose: As sodium ions bind to the SGLT protein, their movement into the cell down the concentration gradient provides the necessary energy for the simultaneous movement of glucose against its concentration gradient. Glucose is "dragged" along with the sodium ions as they enter the cell.
  4. Glucose Transporter: Once inside the epithelial cell, glucose is transported across the basolateral membrane (the inner surface of the cell) and into the bloodstream by facilitated diffusion through a specific glucose transporter called GLUT2.

 

Overall, the energy stored in the sodium gradient created by the sodium-potassium pump is used to actively transport both sodium and glucose into the intestinal epithelial cells. This secondary active transport mechanism allows for the absorption of glucose from the intestinal lumen into the bloodstream efficiently, even when the concentration of glucose is higher inside the cell than in the lumen.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary active transport: Incorrect because primary active transport involves the direct use of ATP to move substances against their gradient, which does not apply to glucose absorption in this context.

 

Option B. Facilitated diffusion: Incorrect as this method does not involve the active transport of glucose against its concentration gradient; it only allows movement along the gradient.

 

Option C. Simple diffusion: Incorrect because simple diffusion does not involve any transport proteins and occurs only along the concentration gradient, which is not sufficient for glucose absorption in the intestine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose absorption in the intestine occurs via secondary active transport, utilizing the energy from the sodium gradient created by the sodium-potassium ATPase to transport glucose against its concentration gradient. This process is crucial for efficient glucose uptake from the intestinal lumen into the bloodstream.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a dietary fiber? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Milk

 

Explanation

 

Major components of dietary fiber are cellulose, hemicelluloses, D-glucans, pectin, lignin and gums. Cellulose, hemicelluloses and pectin are partially degradable, while other components are indigestible. Dietary fiber also contains minerals, antioxidants and other chemicals that are useful for health.

 

Sources of dietary fiber are fruits, vegetables, cereals, bread and wheat grain (particularly its outer layer).

 

Diet with high dietary fiber has health benefits since dietary fiber:

 

  1. Delays emptying of stomach
  2. Increases formation of bulk and soft feces and eases defecation
  3. Contains substances such as antioxidants and other useful substances

 

Diet with high fiber content tends to be low in energy and it may be useful in reducing the body weight.

 

Some components of dietary fiber also reduce blood cholesterol level and thereby decrease the risk for coronary heart disease and gallstones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cellulose: A primary form of dietary fiber found in the cell walls of plants.

 

Option B. Inulin: A type of soluble fiber found in many plants, used by some as a prebiotic to promote gut health.

 

Option C. Pectin: Another soluble fiber, pectin is commonly found in fruits and used to help gel liquids, also aiding in digestion and cholesterol reduction.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Tissue factor

questions.text: Which of the following clotting factors would have decreased gamma carboxyglutamate residue in a patient on warfarin therapy?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Factor 2

 

Explanation

 

Factor 2 would have decreased gamma carboxyglutamate residue in a patient on warfarin therapy.

 

Factors II, VII, IX, X are vitamin k dependent coagulation factors, as their activated by carboxylation of their glutamate residues by enzyme y-glutamyl carboxylase requires vitamin K (reduced form) as a co-factor.

 

This reduced form of vitamin K is constantly oxidized for the reaction to continue. This recycling is done by the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase. This enzyme is inhibited by warfarin. Thus, warfarin affects vitamin k dependent factors.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Factor 11: Incorrect, Factor XI is not vitamin K-dependent and thus not directly affected by warfarin therapy.

 

Option C. Tissue factor: Incorrect, Tissue factor (Factor III) is a different component of the clotting cascade that acts as a receptor and cofactor for Factor VIIa; it is not a vitamin K-dependent factor and is not affected by warfarin.

 

Option D. Factor 5: Incorrect, Factor V is not dependent on vitamin K for its function, so its activity is not diminished by warfarin therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warfarin therapy impacts the function of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors by inhibiting the recycling of vitamin K, crucial for the carboxylation of these factors. Factor 2 (prothrombin) is one of these affected factors, leading to a reduction in its clotting ability in the presence of warfarin, which is utilized therapeutically to prevent thrombosis.
